story:
My name is Javid. I write JAH. My story is about painting in the streets, helping young people along the way, and trying to build community. I do this through murals, youth work and in the next few years, by designing buildings and spaces. 

 

This project is about catapulting my work as a visual artist into a new dimension. I feel it has matured and developed over the last decade, and now I want to publish the work at a much larger scale. I want to bring that Toronto flavour - the hustle and shine, intelligence and diversity - to galleries/school/centres the world over.

 

Yea it's definitely a lofty goal. And worth much more than the $4,000+ I'm reaching for. But the reality is that I see this first exhibition and catalogue of work as the jump-off - the essential components I will need to garner the support and opportunities to show/share internationally.

I've come up with some perk packages to make sure you get your $ worth.  Let me know if you have any other exchanges or arrangements to help support. It's definitely the Kensington way of doing business around here.

In the righteous words of Ian Kamau,

 

Love Love

 

Javid (JAH)

info@185augusta.com

 

 

 

'ALAAMA (SHE KNOWS)

A  Solo Exhibition by Javid (JAH)

Gallery: 185Augusta (185 Augusta Ave, Kensington Market)

Opening Reception is on Thursday, August 23rd from 7-10pm at 185Augusta.

Viewings : Aug 23-31, 2012

 

'Alaama explores the artist's vision of feminine divinity. Through a series of mixed media paintings that experiment with calligraffiti, the work represents an expression of Sufi Islam.

 

THE VISION


Our goal is to present ‘ALAAMA on an international scale - through gallery exhibitions in major cities and the publishing of a catalogue detailing the work and concept of the show.


We are looking to pool resources to organize and execute these two goals,
and it begins with successfully launching the exhibition at Javid’s studio-gallery-home, 185Augusta.


We are requesting your support, be it through material or monetary sponsorship, to be a part of this ambitious and exciting venture.

 

YOUR INVESTMENT

Essentially your contribution is helping to cover the cost of the exhibition and its catalogue.

 

Details about both projects can be found in the SPONSORSHIP PACKAGE, which you can download from 185augusta.com/alaama. 

 

EXHIBITION  $5,650

CATALOGUE $1,000

TOTAL $4,650

 

TOTAL COST OF 'ALAAMA - ARTIST'S INVESTMENT = AMOUNT REQUESTED

$6,650 - $2,000 = $4,650

 

DETAILS ABOUT THE PERKS

So these gifts are really carefully considered since I know a lot of the pieces are out of my people's price brackets :) Check em out:

 

CUSTOM PAINTINGS


Javid will paint a custom art work for sponsors in the $1000+ bracket. This artwork will be painted on a wood panel sized 24” by 36”, featuring either the a name in calligraffiti or a portrait of the female character in ‘ALAAMA.


LIMITED EDITION TSHIRTS


Commemorative tshirts have been designed for the exhibition to recognize contributions of a miminum of $200. The shirt will be designed and printed by Under the Radar Clothing on unisex, sheer jersey cottons.


ART PRINTS


A selection of paintings and murals will be printed on high-quality gloss paper, sized 18” by 12”, to be signed by the artist, and avaialble for purchase on opening night.

story:
Residency Rescue

Greetings!  My name is Catherine Armbrust—I’m fresh off the turnip truck/graduate program at the University of Missouri and getting ready to move out into the wide world.  I recently earned my Master of Fine Arts in Fibers and Sculpture and hope to find a teaching position very soon.  In the meantime, I’ve just been offered a chance for a month long artist residency in Chapala, Mexico.  The kicker is that it starts in 2 weeks! 

This is a big chance for a fledgling artist trying to move out in the professional world and I want to take advantage of this amazing opportunity I’ve been given.  I just need a little help getting there—literally.  Because I would be traveling last minute at the height of the holiday season, ticket prices are quite high and I am having trouble coming up with the cash to make it happen.  The thought of being away from my loved ones over the holidays makes me sad, but I know that the universe is presenting me with a wonderful gift—a chance to spend a concentrated amount of time making art and preparing my body, mind, and spirit for what comes next in my life. 

The Rest of the Story

Update:  Early ticket projections were misread--THANK GOODNESS!!!  THE TICKET ACTUALLY COSTS ABOUT $1200 INSTEAD OF THE PROJECTED $2200.  BREATHING A SIGH OF RELIEF HERE TODAY...

I am actually very afraid of flying, but want to push past my fear and focus on the wonders that await me in Mexico.  Rather than worry about the flight and the cost I want to practice “faith in action”—I understand that this is pricey, but this is an opportunity of a lifetime and I don’t want to let it get away!  That’s why I’m reaching out to you.  Though my stated goal for the campaign is $500, I would love to meet and beat that goal.  Any money you contribute to my campaign will go to cover my travel expenses to and from Guadalajara, Mexico.  Anything over the price of the plane ticket will go towards food/living expenses while I am there for the month.

Creative Thinking

I want to share my handiwork with my contributors to show you just how much this experience means to me.  I am a mixed media/assemblage artist that works with found objects, knitting/crocheting, and more.  You can see my various bodies of work at www.catherinearmbrust.com.  I have a project in mind to work on while I am in Mexico—a series of collages dealing with masking and personal ornamentation (a continuation of a recent project), plus some possible site-specific installations.  But I also want to create a series of small collages to share with you folks who’ve helped make this a reality!  Different levels of donations will receive one-of-a-kind collages made while I am in Mexico (to be mailed when I arrive back in the U.S.).

Gratitude

I studied abroad in Mexico while at the University of Missouri in the early 90’s.  I feel like this chance to return would almost be like I’m coming full circle after attending MU again to get my Master of Fine Arts.  I feel so blessed to have this chance to make art while immersed in an amazing culture and blessed that you have taken the time to read this.  This is the first time I’ve asked the public for anything like this before—please know how much your contribution would mean to me and to my creative spirit.  I know times are tough for folks right now; even if you can’t contribute, I’d appreciate you sharing my project with others who might be interested.

story:
Lemonade Stand

Lemonade Stand is a collaborative publication documenting a guerrilla gardening tour in vacant lots across America.  In this age of genetically modified seeds, destroyed soil, and ever growing urban communities, knowing where to source organic food for both people and pollinators has become increasingly important.
We will be spreading wildflower seeds in desolate urban areas in hopes of attracting pollinators as well providing wild foods and capturing the existing landscape on film. We are asking for $1,500 to cover the expenses of seeds, film, and the final prints & books.

Who We Are & What We Do

Alysha Colangeli has been residing in the high desert of New Mexico for the past year and a half working with local scientists, farmers, and beekeepers on a number of projects experimenting with the possibilities of growth in barren lands or blank canvases (lichen growth on canvas), oyster mushroom remediation (to potentially clean oil spills and radioactive waste), and issues regarding the deaths of so many bees. Having worked for a local herbalist during her stay in New Mexico, her knowledge in wild foods and foraging has grown exponentially. She received a BFA in Fine Arts from the School of Visual Arts in Manhattan with a focus on Ecological Art & Design. Her work explores the patterns, cycles, and mysticism that occurs within the natural world and universe, and its place and potentials in our current age. She aims to reference deeper environmental and political issues, and touch upon what the human experience means for the rest of the natural world.

Chelsea Pfohl is a Brooklyn based fine art photographer and visual artist. She received her BFA from NYU in Studio Art and Creative Writing. Shooting film - 35mm and medium format - she captures light and color while connecting viewer to subject and connecting seemingly arbitrary subjects with each other. Her latest ongoing project is a reaction to the way she processes whatever she currently is “involved” with—who she spends time with, what she is reading, researching, watching, talking about and listening to. The constant is an obsessive fixation with light and color, regardless of subject (which in her work is both fleeting and arbitrary). Light and color are what catch her eye, determines the focus of her lens and is ultimately what unites her work into one cohesive body.

Ways You Can Help

Support our collaboration by donating, any little bit helps! 

Spread the word!

Follow us on instagram @sacred_geometry and @nonochelsea for updates on our journey!

story:
CREATIVITY WITHOUT BORDERS.

We were somewhere outside of Barstow, on the edge of the desert, when the art began to take hold.

The creative expanse of an artist's mind is boundless, limitless, a primed surface tense with potential. This is an experiment, a journey to reconfigure a physical world created by the necessities of a society that saw fit to draw clearly defined borders in the sacred realm of artistic expression. This is an exercise in finding the strength to break down those borders. This is an opportunity to take the shortest distance between two points into the realm of the non-linear.

THIS IS US VERSUS BORDER LINES

This Is Us Versus Border Lines is an epic 10 day creative cross-country art excursion accompanied by video and blog documentation that includes fine art, tagging and graffiti, wheatpasting, and 3D projection mapping of urban spaces that will culminate in a guerilla-style gallery exhibition projected onto the side of buildings throughout the destination ­displaying the individual and collaborative work of two artists with drastically different approaches to the creative process. Their work on this journey, while heavily informed by the limitations that exist within their own lives, will focus on a transference of the physical spaces they explore into a new world and the creation of a personal truth devoid of border lines.

  • This Is Us Versus Borderlines will take us from Atlanta to Los Angeles in 10 Days.
  • The journey will be filmed, photographed, blogged, and streamed live daily, ultimately leading to the production of a full-length documentary. 
  • Along the way, we will create individual and collaborative fine art, street art, and project video and still imagery onto urban spaces and natural structures. 
  • We will invite feedback and contribution from passers by as well as arrange collaborations with local artists along the way. 
  • The final exposition of work created over the course of this project will be a web-broadcasted impromptu "projection bombing" of buildings along Gallery Row during an LA Art Walk, where up to 70,000 people will be engaged in the results of this project. 
  • The successful funding of this project will be used to help launch This Is Us Versus into overdrive. Immediately following the completion of Border Lines, we will begin organizing our next project.
  • We need help surpassing this funding goal and spreading the word about this project through any media outlet or social networking utility. 

WHO IS THIS IS US VERSUS?

This Is Us Versus is a burgeoning bicoastal art collective that focuses on providing resources, networking, and exhibition opportunities for talented emerging artists that struggle to secure them in their communities due to the subject matter or execution of their work. From street art to controversial art and contemporary surrealism, from Guerilla projection bombing of urban spaces to animated films, it is the mission of This Is Us Versus to ensure that nothing worth seeing is ever overlooked.

WHO ARE THE CO-OWNERS AND WHERE CAN I SEE THEIR WORK?

Aesthetic Cataclysm - Co-Owner, Art Director

http://www.aestheticcataclysm.com

E.Marston - Co-Owner, Founder

http://emarston.wix.com/emarston

 

HELP US TRANSCEND BORDERS, CONTRIBUTORS CAN TOUCH THE RADIO!

By contributing to this project, you are contributing to every future endeavor of This Is Us Versus. While this particular project is the culmination of several years of hard work building the connections and support to begin larger projects, This Is Us Versus Border Lines is just the beginning. Every gifted artist deserves the exhibition opportunities that This Is Us Versus will provide.  In 2011, TIUV organized the most highly attended underground art exhibition in Atlanta by an order of magnitude, showcasing the work of over two dozen artists and giving several of them the first sale they had ever made. We only hope to grow from there. Whether it's organizing a national surrealist art exhibition to accompany the work of Alex Grey in Atlanta this fall, or bombing the streets of Los Angeles with building-sized projections of fine art from emerging artists, every great achievement begins with a journey. This is ours.

  • This Is Us Versus Border Lines has a funding goal of at least $3500. That said, every contribution, no matter how small or how large, even if it is not monetary, is absolutely invaluable to us and every artist that we have or will affiliate with.
  • Monetary contributions will help us along our journey to fund art supplies, video equipment, travel expenses like gas and lodging, and maybe something to put in our starving artist tummies. We are also accepting lodging donations and would love to share our encounters with other artists and art enthusiasts along the way. So check the route and see if we'll be stomping through your town.
  • What's in it for you? This Is Us Versus will offer rewards for contributions! Rewards include desktop backgrounds, the best hugs ever, signed and numbered fine art prints, a DVD of the This Is Us Versus Border Lines documentary, limited edition T-shirts, all of the original artwork created along the way, and several larger collaborative studio paintings inspired by the journey.
  • Follow Along At Home! The route will be posted online for all to see (and likely deviated from heavily as we explore the limitless scope of this creative endeavor),  as well as a daily blog for all to follow us as we make our way across the country, This Is Us Versus Style!
  • The most effective way to contribute to this project is to share it with the world, just as This Is Us Versus Borders will be shared. The culmination of this project is a guerilla style projection bombing gallery exhibition broadcast online showcasing the work created over the course of this journey and excerpts from the footage taken along the way. There is a limitless world open to us, please help us connect with others by sharing this project, and thank you all! 

Don't Forget All The Perks and Sample Art Works!

 The "This Is Us Versus" Tee

And HOT DAMN! That was some good music, right? 

Check out "Die Rad" from Maniac! 
http://www.facebook.com/ManiacMania
http://soundcloud.com/maniac-jake-g

story:
My name is Tamarisk Wood. I was born and raised in Las Vegas and have lived here my entire life.

I went to The Las Vegas Academy of Performing & Visual Arts from it's opening year in 1993. During that time i became a cafe' kid. Enigma, Copioh, Roma... I was always at one of them. I met amazing, remarkable people who inspired me, and fell in love with coffee culture.

I started my first Barista job in 1999 near UNLV. While working there, I started booking live local bands, and monthly exhibits of local artists. I also DJ'd and had 3 club nights, but clubs just didn't give the creative outlet I wanted, despite my attempts to bring art into the mix. So in 2002 I put on my first art & music festival at The Arts Factory, called Avant Garden. The festival featured 4 bands & 15 Artists. The next year, in March of 2003, we put on the second and final festival at The Arts Factory.

After a short break, I started a First Friday pre-Get Back party at The Beauty Bar in 2005. I hung art on the walls, had DJs, and live bands like The Bleachers, Big Friendly Corporation and What 4 You, as well as performance artists & burlesque. It was a ton of fun!

I stopped doing that show once I started my biggest project to date, The Epicenter Gallery on Main & Charleston. From December 2005-2008, every First Friday I curated 3 rooms with 3 different artists, and quite often, themed group shows featuring some of Vegas' best known & prolific artists, including Casey Weldon, Juan Muniz, Amy Sol, Mike Biggs, Roxy & Albert Montoya and Cuca Refugia. I also booked live music in The Backroom each month, with the bands Give 'Em Hell, HOTS, The Skooners, Listener, Dr. Popsicle And the Hair-Painted Opera House, and many Macro-Fi acts among the performers who played The Epicenter over the years. It was a lot of work and organizing, but with help from all of the amazing artists, bands, and the community, I was able to put on fresh shows every month.

Currently I'm curating at Sunrise Coffee, as well as The 3rd Street Farmers Market and occasionally putting on benefit shows for local charities. I'm also helping book Common Ground after party every First Friday.

I'm still a Barista. I've worked at huge corporations, franchises, and small independents. I've worked from starting level to managing a corporate cafe for several years. I understand Cafe management and know the needs of the business from every level and angle.

I love Las Vegas. I love our art & music community. And I love making beautiful, yummy coffee. Seeing that smile after the first sip, as silly as it seems, makes me giddy.

I've wanted my own cafe & art gallery for years, but at 32 years old, I finally feel I have the experience and maturity to create a space that will be around for a very long time; to become a home for artists, musicians, writers, thinkers, and friends to come together and make Las Vegas even better.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute monetarily, you can still help Avant become reality!

You can spread the word on Facebook, Twitter, or your blog. You can write a quick email to the weeklies or newspapers and maybe the campaign will get a write-up.

If you have any restaurant equipment, from commercial refrigerators or blenders, an espresso machine, or anything you think could help cut costs, please let me know.

If you'd like to help put on fundraisers outside of the internet, in the real world, I'd be more than happy to help put it together with you.

Don't forget Indiegogo makes it easy for you & has share tools!

story:
The Awiya Project: Art that Gives. 

All around us, people are in need. Personal tragedies occur on a daily basis, and touch our lives through family, friends, co- workers, neighbors, etc. A great many of us find ourselves unprepared when these life changing events occur, and all to often need to seek assistance. Many times this assistance is sought by way of benefit events, auctions and sales. There exists a need for quality items to draw interest and money to these fundraising events, and that is where The Awiya Project wants to help.

 

The Awiya Project is currently utilizing a crowd funding campaign to raise the money needed to create quality fine art to be donated to these benefit events. And while these charitable donations are the general focus of The Awiya Project, we also are available for donations to public venues to provide public art. Small community public libraries, schools, and public meeting spaces are all places deserving of public art to inspire the creative spark in all people. The artists of The Awiya project provide their time and talent, while the funds of the crowd funding campaign provide the materials, so that a high quality, finished work of art can be available to people, groups and organizations in need. We hope to inspire not only those that view the work, but other artist as well, to engage the giving spirit and answer the call for help in our communities.

Inspiration, expression, and compassionate giving are the core values in The Awiya Project. We hope to awaken the light within all people, to invigorate the sense of community, so that giving hands can reach across great distances, and strengthen bond of interconnectedness that ties us all. We are one people, one world.

 

 

The Awiya Project - Art that Gives

Simply put The Awiya Project is about giving, about helping others, about building a better world through art.

My wife, Lou, and I have been artists, well, all our lives.  Her career began at Minneapolis College of Art and Design, and mine began as a child, as far back as I can remember.  We are working artists, living in rural Nebraska.  Helping others has been a major part of our lives as well.  Lou & I work for a nonprofit organization as   Community Support Professionasl as our day jobs, her career spanning 20 years and I began participating in fundraising efforts as a child, raising money for Jerry's kid with my uncle every year, who suffered from Duchene Muscular Dystrophy.  Helping others is just a part of who we are.

With increasing frequency, we are asked to donate one of our pieces for various fundraising efforts.  And while we have yet to turn anyone away, it becomes more difficult to keep purchasing art materials when we are giving the paintings away.  I made a casual comment on my facebook page oneday, about how I wish there was crowdfunding for artists.  I was entirely unaware this amazing venue, Indiegogo, even existed.  Thanks to a tip from a friend, an idea was born.

We want to GIVE every single piece we create for six months away!  All of them.  With one small catch - we want to give them to fundraising auctions, charity sales, public libraries and other public venues, etc.  We want our art to help people.  To provide aid to those that need it, give inspiration to those who might not otherwise have it, to do good in the world.  Art that gives, that really truly gives.  That is what we want to do... with your help.

So, how can you help?

Art is, well, expensive.  Quality materials, which produce beautiful works that last for literally generations, cost more than most people think.  A tube of decent paint that can be used for thick applications is about $18.99 plus tax, for a tube that fits in the palm of your hand.  But a higher pigment load (more color saturation) used in thinner applications, well a tiny tube of that stuff can cost upwards of $30, and believe me they are small tubes, about the size of your thumb.  And then there are rolls of canvas, boards, stretcher bars, gesso and such that go into just making the surface that gets painted.  Brushes, mixing mediums, drying mediums, varnish and all manner of products that go into the painting itself besides just paint.  Two new travel easels will be needed so we can work en plein air as much as possible, so that we may interact with the public and get the word out.  And we like to frame as many pieces as possible, especially in this case, so that the fundraising effort receives a final product, rather than one that would include additional investment.  And of course, shipping materials and expenses.  All of these things are the reason why you always hear the phrase 'starving artist.'  It is insanely expensive.

So we are asking for your help in funding a portion of these costs, (we also will have to use close to 10%, or more depending on final amount, of the funds raised here as fees and costs of using Indiegogo and payment processors), so that for six months, two artists can give every single piece they create away, in a manner that helps other people, so that the cycle of giving continues.  Pay it forward, as it were.

Other little ways The Awiya Project helps -

In addition to creating the art that then gets donated to fundraising efforts, we also make our art purchases in mindful ways as often as possible.  If we can purchase materials through a place that offers a percentage of the sale to a worthy cause, we do.  If we  can find a vendor that then, in turn, supports community art projects, then we purchase through them.  Even the rags we use to clean our brushes, we purchase at a local thrift shop that takes donationed items, and uses all the proceeds to aid local senior citizens.  Lou and I make every attempt to be an active part in the community of giving as often as we can.  Changing the world occurs through one act of kindness at a time.

Want to help, but don't have the cash?

You can still help, and we still need it!  Tell people about us!  Get the word out.  Like our Facebook fan page, visit our website (often), follow us on twitter (and use the hashtag #AwiyaProject), tell people about our blogs and our pages.  Help us reach out to as many people as we can, so we can all reach as many lives as possible, and change the world one piece of art at a time.

If we do not reach our target goal, we will use the funds we do receive to extend The Awiya Project as long as we can.  In other words, if we only reach half the funding goal, that probably puts us at about half the time. But we have timed the creation of the Project to take us through the end of 2012.  We hope to spend the entirety of the remaining year dedicated to helping as many people as possible.  And while we will not be creating any works to sell during The Awiya Project, any proceeds from print sales from these paintings will be put right back into The Awiya Project.  We want the cycle of giving to last as long as it possibly can.  We hope to never sell another painting ever again!

 

 

The Awiya Project - Art that Gives!
story_txt:
The Awiya Project: Art that Gives.  
All around us, people are in need. Personal tragedies occur on a daily basis, and touch our lives through family, friends, co- workers, neighbors, etc. A great many of us find ourselves unprepared when these life changing events occur, and all to often need to seek assistance. Many times this assistance is sought by way of benefit events, auctions and sales. There exists a need for quality items to draw interest and money to these fundraising events, and that is where The Awiya Project wants to help. 
 
The Awiya Project is currently utilizing a crowd funding campaign to raise the money needed to create quality fine art to be donated to these benefit events. And while these charitable donations are the general focus of The Awiya Project, we also are available for donations to public venues to provide public art. Small community public libraries, schools, and public meeting spaces are all places deserving of public art to inspire the creative spark in all people. The artists of The Awiya project provide their time and talent, while the funds of the crowd funding campaign provide the materials, so that a high quality, finished work of art can be available to people, groups and organizations in need. We hope to inspire not only those that view the work, but other artist as well, to engage the giving spirit and answer the call for help in our communities.
 Inspiration, expression, and compassionate giving are the core values in The Awiya Project. We hope to awaken the light within all people, to invigorate the sense of community, so that giving hands can reach across great distances, and strengthen bond of interconnectedness that ties us all. We are one people, one world. 
 
 
The Awiya Project - Art that Gives 
Simply put The Awiya Project is about giving, about helping others, about building a better world through art.
My wife, Lou, and I have been artists, well, all our lives.  Her career began at Minneapolis College of Art and Design, and mine began as a child, as far back as I can remember.  We are working artists, living in rural Nebraska.  Helping others has been a major part of our lives as well.  Lou & I work for a nonprofit organization as   Community Support Professionasl as our day jobs, her career spanning 20 years and I began participating in fundraising efforts as a child, raising money for Jerry's kid with my uncle every year, who suffered from Duchene Muscular Dystrophy.  Helping others is just a part of who we are.
With increasing frequency, we are asked to donate one of our pieces for various fundraising efforts.  And while we have yet to turn anyone away, it becomes more difficult to keep purchasing art materials when we are giving the paintings away.  I made a casual comment on my facebook page oneday, about how I wish there was crowdfunding for artists.  I was entirely unaware this amazing venue, Indiegogo, even existed.  Thanks to a tip from a friend, an idea was born.

In addition to creating the art that then gets donated to fundraising efforts, we also make our art purchases in mindful ways as often as possible.  If we can purchase materials through a place that offers a percentage of the sale to a worthy cause, we do.  If we  can find a vendor that then, in turn, supports community art projects, then we purchase through them.  Even the rags we use to clean our brushes, we purchase at a local thrift shop that takes donationed items, and uses all the proceeds to aid local senior citizens.  Lou and I make every attempt to be an active part in the community of giving as often as we can.  Changing the world occurs through one act of kindness at a time.
Want to help, but don't have the cash?
You can still help, and we still need it!  Tell people about us!  Get the word out.  Like our Facebook fan page, visit our website (often), follow us on twitter (and use the hashtag #AwiyaProject), tell people about our blogs and our pages.  Help us reach out to as many people as we can, so we can all reach as many lives as possible, and change the world one piece of art at a time.
If we do not reach our target goal, we will use the funds we do receive to extend The Awiya Project as long as we can.  In other words, if we only reach half the funding goal, that probably puts us at about half the time. But we have timed the creation of the Project to take us through the end of 2012.  We hope to spend the entirety of the remaining year dedicated to helping as many people as possible.  And while we will not be creating any works to sell during The Awiya Project, any proceeds from print sales from these paintings will be put right back into The Awiya Project.  We want the cycle of giving to last as long as it possibly can.  We hope to never sell another painting ever again!

story:
Short Summary

My name is Otilia Kocsis and I'm a Patras (Greece) located artist, who is mainly inspired by the Mediterranean landscape beauty. My usual medium is the watercolor on paper, and although from time to time I do experiment other media too, you can get an idea about my watercolors on my Watercolor Gallery web site.

I volunteered to teach a 30 weeks workshop (1 session of 2 hours per week, ) in watercolor painting to retired women (aged over 60 years old) at one of the community centers in my city (Patras, Greece). The workshop is foreseen as 1 session of 2 hours per week, it will start in September 2014 and will end in June 2015. The number of ladies expected to attend in the first group is about 15 (10 already confirmed).

The community center has space and infrastructure (room to host the workshop, furniture, etc) to support the project, but there are no any funds to support with the necessary materials, like watercolor paper, paints, brushes, sketch blocks, pencils, etc. Due to the crisis, it is almost impossible to find any governmental support for this workshop. Also, I cannot afford to pay these by myself, thus I am trying to find alternative ways to raise the necessary funds.

All the money raised will be spent to get the necessary materials for the workshop. If more than the target amount is raised, they will be used either to have a second workshop group, or to continue with the group for another 30 weeks (September 2015 to June 2016).


What We Need

The funding schema for this project is flexible, and we shall start the project with any funds we manage to get for the beginning, hopping we will get more on the way. To give you an idea of what materials are needed for the workshop, we have established some value-dependent kits and needs that they cover. The milestones gives you an idea about how the project will be implemented with the raised funds.

Kits

Starter Kit. It is estimated at approximately 35 US$, and it covers a set of cheap materials needed by each lady for the first 5 sessions of the workshop. It includes: (a) one Cotman watercolour box (small plastic palette + 12 half pans watercolor paints + a small brush); (b) 2 cheap brushes; (c) 2 sheets of watercolor paper; (d) pencil and sketchpad

Beginner Kit. It is estimated at approximately 80 US$, and it covers a set of cheap/student grade materials needed by each lady for half-year (15 sessions) of the workshop. It includes: (a) one Cotman watercolour box (small plastic palette + 12 half pans watercolor paints + a small brush) and one set of refilling watercolor pans or tubes; (b) 3 cheap brushes, (c) 8 sheets of watercolour paper; (d) pencils and sketchpads

Full Kit. It is estimated at approximately 300 US$, and it covers a full set of student/artist grade materials needed by each lady for the full-year (30 sessions) of the workshop. It includes: (a) one watercolour folding palette, (b) 5 watercolor brushes, (c) a set of 12 watercolour paints for the entire duration of the workshop, (d) 25 sheets of watercolour paper; (e) pencils and sketchpads; (f) other materials (boards, mediums).

Milestones

1st Milestone: 150 US$. It covers: ~3 Starter Kits (+ ~45US$ indiegogo and bank fees)

2nd Milestone: 500 US$. It covers:~10 Starter Kits (+ ~85 US$ indiegogo and bank fees)

3rd Milestone: 1000 US$. It covers: ~ 10 Beginner Kits (+ ~150 US$ indiegogo and bank fees)

4th Milestone: 1500 US$. It covers: ~ 15 Beginner Kits (+ ~220 US$ indiegogo and bank fees)

5th Milestone: 3500 US$. It covers: ~ 10 Full Kits (+ ~400 US$ indiegogo and bank fees)

6th Milestone: 5000 US$. It covers: 15 Full Kits (+ ~550 indiegogo and bank fees)


What You Get

My way to thank you for your financial support go make this project reach the goal is to send you either high quality prints (professional materials) of some of my paintings or to paint for you custom floral original watercolors. Depending on size, each original painting will take some time to complete, but I will try to deliver all of them as fast as possible.

The print-perks will be delivered to you in a maximum of 2 weeks after the confirmation of your contribution. You can choose to get a print of one of the following paintings.


Print 01


Print 02


Print 03


Print 04


Print 05


Print 06


Print 07


Print 08


Print 09


Print 10


Print 11


Print 12


For all the perks, either original paintings or prints, the shipping is included to any location worldwide.


Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot help financially to this project, just spread the word around and it is already more than doing nothing! Thank you in advance!

story:
Company Overview:

In the winter of 2008, outdoor adventure guide Cassandra Styles took on a different kind of challenge. The local "sheltered workshop" (old term) for adults with developmental disabilities was in need of an overhaul, and members of the community thought she was just the woman to do it. Styles, a mixed-media artist and accomplished entrepreneur, re-invented the business as a “day program” (new term) that nurtured creativity, growth, respect, and community inclusion. The participants named the program Shortbus Studio because after a lifetime of riding small yellow buses, they wanted to make it cool. Under Styles’ direction, the program has become a nationally celebrated model for facilitated learning through a variety of art, volunteer, educational, and outdoor adventure activities.

Mission:

The mission of Shortbus Studio is to help bridge barriers between people and communities, and to teach us that in the end, we are more alike than we are different.  

Funding Needs:

Shortbus Studio participants need a new wheelchair accessible bus. Specifically, a bus with a 12 passenger capacity and room for two wheelchairs plus a driver. Upgrading to aluminum wheels would lower maintenance costs and reduce fuel consumption and greenhouse gas emissions. Installing a backup camera would allow the driver to see in places that mirrors cannot. Adding cargo nets would help keep riders safe by preventing outdoor gear, art equipment, or any other items from coming loose in the rear of the bus. Also, foldaway seats would make each trip easier by providing multiple wheelchair/seating arrangements and allow more room for locking in wheelchairs. Safety is the biggest priority for Shortbus Studio, but the vehicles in use now are not safe due to years of wear and tear, high mileage, multiple breakdowns and unreliable wheelchair lifts. A new wheelchair accessible bus costs $65,000. With your help Shortbus Studio can continue to be an inspiration and model for other organizations. They can continue exploring ways to use adventures, volunteering and the arts to build collaborations and everyday relationships with members of the community. With your help they can continue to educate the public on how individuals with disabilities are much more alike than different from them.

Shortbus Studio participants are convinced that they can raise the $65,000 needed to purchase a new bus; however, if they don't reach their entire goal, all funds will go towards vehicle maintenance, program activities, art supplies and much needed studio repairs.  

Why Shortbus Studio Is Important:

As a longtime advocate for people with disabilities, Cassandra Styles thought nothing could sound less cool to her than a program where people with disabilities are segregated and confined in one space all day, sitting at tables doing repetitive piece work for which they are paid very little. She believed that isolating, boring "sheltered workshops" could be transformed into inclusive spaces where the arts, community engagement, and adventure are primary elements. She hoped that Shortbus Studio would become an inspiration and model for other programs serving adults with special needs, and provide participants opportunities to help others in their community instead of always being the ones perceived as needing help.    

To date, Shortbus Studio participants have worked in community gardens that feed hungry people; made chew toys for animal shelters, provided hands-on care of rescued Syrian bear cubs for a zoo, volunteered for sea turtle rescue, river and beach clean-ups, and food banks.  They have volunteered on farms, shelved books in school libraries, and served as Big Sisters/Big Brothers to young residents of nursing homes. Shortbus Studio participants enjoy weekly art projects. mountain hikes, horseback riding, whitewater rafting, zip lining, kayaking and anything else they can think of that’s adventuresome and fun. Their motto is "Get outside and play!"  By helping keep Shortbus Studio on the road, you make it possible for them to continue going out to make good things happen in their community and the world.   

Other Ways You Can Help:

Anyone can help contribute, even if you're short on cash. Help Shortbus Studio get the word out by making some noise about this campaign and increasing your good karma by using the Indiegogo share tools. Tell your friends. That's all there is to it. Plus, as an extra bonus for folks who can donate $50 or more, the Shortbus Studio will send you one of their original, 100% cotton, limited edition, fine art tee shirts. Wear the Shortbus logo with pride!  Also, you can send a contribution to:

Shortbus Studio                                                                                                                               PO BOX 849                                                                                                                         Burnsville, NC 28714

story:
Going Vintage in a Digital World?

In recent years there has been a movement of camera manufacturer's going vintage, creating cameras that look like yesteryear's but with today's technology. Photography is rooted in capturing moments and documenting a present that is tomorrow's past, so it's only natural that the photographer has a streak of nostalgia. In my journey to becoming a better photographer, my affinity for history created a curiosity about the progression of equipment and techniques that got us to where we are today. 

Photography has been one of my passions since I was very young, and in recent years I have focused a great deal of attention on developing the craft. I have always been a photographer on a budget, so I have always looked for ways to innovate within my means. In my research about the progression of cameras, I stumbled across an article that highlighted the advantages of going with film even in today's digital world.  This set my mind in motion.  This was the kind of challenge that appealed to me.  

Working with a vintage Yashica A Medium Format Twin Lens Reflex camera, is a test of skill.  Every time you shoot with film you have to make it count. You have to become better at composing to get good images.  It forces you to slow down and look at the scene and decide what angle you like, instead of shooting from every possible angle and sorting it out later. 

The Project
Part 1: Complete!!!

Part 2: After the camera is fighting fit, I plan to do a series of shoots to test the camera's limitations and to build experience with the Yashica A. Shooting will be centered around the theme: a day in the life of Des Moines County, Iowa. The range of shots will cover Landscapes/Cityscapes/Landmarks , Architecture, & Still Life. I will be shooting with black and white film, and infrared film.  This will help in the development of a class that will focus specifically on film photography, that will be available through the Art Center of Burlington. Your contribution will cover a portion of the cost of purchasing and processing film.

Part 3:   The final objective of this project is to produce a gallery exhibit featuring the best images from the project. This portion will help create enthusiasm for film photography, for the class, and will generate revenue for the Art Center of Burlington as 30% of the proceeds from prints from this project and from sales of prints during the showing will go to the Art Center of Burlington.  The contribution to the Art Center will help provide funds for community art projects & programs, as well as promotion of local artists.

    The Perks

    The Perks are meant to be stackable. If there is more than one packages that you are interested in please feel free to contact me, and we can work out the best way to get you what you want.

    The Impact

    By supporting this project your are ensuring the continuation of the knowledge base about shooting with vintage cameras. You are preserving a part of our history and a tool of expressing our humanity. You are fueling a movement that has already began to bubble to the surface. For example, just this year I saw where Popular Photography used double exposure for their theme for one of their monthly photo contests. Double exposure is from the era of cameras like the Yashica A, before double exposure protection was incorporated into the camera design. Before this design change it was possible to forget to wind the film before taking the next shot exposing an already exposed frame in which the two different scenes are superimposed. Now cameras and software are incorporating these effects as a means of furthering creativity. Without your support we can not produce the gallery exhibit, which is the heart and soul of this project. This is our greatest tool for promoting awareness of the value of vintage cameras (of all types) and of the past developments that have shaped our viewpoints of the art form of photography.

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Spreading the word is the best way you can help. Please share this project with your friends, family, and maybe even a few strangers. If you have a couple rolls of 120 film that you can spare that would be awesome too! We can always use advice.

In my journey to becoming a better photographer, my affinity for history created a curiosity about the progression of equipment and techniques that got us to where we are today. 
Photography has been one of my passions since I was very young, and in recent years I have focused a great deal of attention on developing the craft. I have always been a photographer on a budget, so I have always looked for ways to innovate within my means. In my research about the progression of cameras, I stumbled across an article that highlighted the advantages of going with film even in today's digital world.  This set my mind in motion.  This was the kind of challenge that appealed to me.  
Working with a vintage Yashica A Medium Format Twin Lens Reflex camera, is a test of skill.  Every time you shoot with film you have to make it count. You have to become better at composing to get good images.  It forces you to slow down and look at the scene and decide what angle you like, instead of shooting from every possible angle and sorting it out later. 
  The ProjectPart 1: Complete!!!

Part 2: After the camera is fighting fit, I plan to do a series of shoots to test the camera's limitations and to build experience with the Yashica A. Shooting will be centered around the theme: a day in the life of Des Moines County, Iowa. The range of shots will cover Landscapes/Cityscapes/Landmarks , Architecture, & Still Life. I will be shooting with black and white film, and infrared film.  This will help in the development of a class that will focus specifically on film photography, that will be available through the Art Center of Burlington. Your contribution will cover a portion of the cost of purchasing and processing film.
Part 3:   The final objective of this project is to produce a gallery exhibit featuring the best images from the project. This portion will help create enthusiasm for film photography, for the class, and will generate revenue for the Art Center of Burlington as 30% of the proceeds from prints from this project and from sales of prints during the showing will go to the Art Center of Burlington.  The contribution to the Art Center will help provide funds for community art projects & programs, as well as promotion of local artists.



  The Perks
The Perks are meant to be stackable. If there is more than one packages that you are interested in please feel free to contact me, and we can work out the best way to get you what you want.

The Impact By supporting this project your are ensuring the continuation of the knowledge base about shooting with vintage cameras. You are preserving a part of our history and a tool of expressing our humanity. You are fueling a movement that has already began to bubble to the surface. For example, just this year I saw where Popular Photography used double exposure for their theme for one of their monthly photo contests. Double exposure is from the era of cameras like the Yashica A, before double exposure protection was incorporated into the camera design. Before this design change it was possible to forget to wind the film before taking the next shot exposing an already exposed frame in which the two different scenes are superimposed. Now cameras and software are incorporating these effects as a means of furthering creativity. Without your support we can not produce the gallery exhibit, which is the heart and soul of this project. This is our greatest tool for promoting awareness of the value of vintage cameras (of all types) and of the past developments that have shaped our viewpoints of the art form of photography.




  Other Ways You Can Help Spreading the word is the best way you can help. Please share this project with your friends, family, and maybe even a few strangers. If you have a couple rolls of 120 film that you can spare that would be awesome too! We can always use advice.

story:
My Challenge 

Typically, the University of Alaska, Anchorage provides students the opportunity to apply for an Undergraduate Research Grant. Due to university-wide budget cuts, grant funding has been cut by 50%. This means I can only apply to receive $1,000 of the $3,200 needed to complete my thesis.  

I've been working towards this moment for the last five years so I want to document my work and also ensure it's available to experience in person. 

My Experience 

Since 2015, my work has been featured in numerous group shows in addition to a solo gallery show in June 2019. Locations include the International Gallery of Contemporary Art, Akela Space, and the Hugh McPeck Gallery along with various showcases at local businesses. Four works were accepted into juried art shows with three awarded honorable mentions. 

My Work

My work is influenced by Minimalism and Non-objectivity. Emphasis is placed on order, simplicity, materiality, and placement. I've been experimenting with optical illusions to alter the viewer’s sense of perspective. Materials like steel rod and string don't take up very much space volumetrically but have the potential to take up a large amount of space visually. 

The goal is to create artwork that envelops the viewer and invites them to move around the space that I’ve constructed.  Playing with the viewer's sense of spatial awareness forces them to focus only on what is in front of them, thus creating a truly in-the-moment-experience.

My Background 

I'm currently in my senior year of my Bachelor of Fine Arts Degree at the University of Alaska, Anchorage. In 2015, I moved from Tennessee to Alaska and enrolled in UAA. I was quickly drawn to the Fine Arts Program and the amazing faculty. With their support and direction, I applied to the BFA program and was accepted. 

Because UAA runs its BFA program like a Masters program, I am required to research, write, and defend a thesis that becomes an exhibition at the end of the Spring semester.  This exhibition is the culmination of years of research and hard work and is the final step in receiving my degree.

 

The Need

The budget set for this project is $3,200. (Because of the site-specific nature of the work and university regulations, the work cannot be sold. Therefore expenses cannot be recouped through the sale of the artwork.)

The breakdown of costs:

  • $540 for supplies
  • $550 gallery rental fee
    • My exhibition will occur at Akela Space. Because my installations cannot be offered for sale to the public, we have agreed upon a flat rate in lieu of commission 
  • $1,300 professional documentation of work
    • Because of the nature of my work, it is extremely difficult to document properly. So I'm bringing in the professionals! They will document my exhibition through both photo and video - allowing me to use the documentation for my portfolio, website, and share the exhibition with those who are not able to see it in person whether it's because of location or Covid-19 precautions. 
  • $220 for posters and postcards
    • A BFA requirement to order these from the university 
  • Perk Production
    • Material and production costs  
      • Tent City Press studio fee
      • Zines 
      • Handmade relief printed & exhibition photo greeting cards
      • Exhibition Prints 
      • Stickers
  • Indiegogo campaign fees
    • 5% platform fee
    • 2.9% + $0.30 fee per transaction 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Any amount you're willing to give helps! I know this isn't an easy time for everyone financially (myself included), but you can help me out even just by sharing this page.

story:
Overview

Calendar. Use it to track time. Stare at artwork of Yosemite. Wish you were in Yosemite. Go to Yosemite? Plan the trip on the calendar. Very useful. Very inspirational. 

Hi! I’m Laura Hollingsworth, here to share some of my favorite Yosemite artwork.

I’m a self-taught freelance illustrator from Virginia. You may know me as the creator of The Silver Eye, a drawer of Narnia and Lunar Chronicles fanart, or just some random person on the internet. All of these things are true. Yes, all of them.

One of my favorite places in the world — and, therefore, one of my favorite things to draw — is Yosemite National Park. 

Recently, my family has started to go on regular pilgrimages to this wonderful National Park. I’ve spent a lot of time studying this beautiful scenery, and now I want to share it with you. 

In the 8.5"x11" wall calendar, you’ll find…

Traditional art.

Digital art.

Small, detailed moments. 

Grand vistas.

 

Twelve months of studies for you to enjoy all year long. 

Perks

The Silver Eye Postcards

Four postcards featuring people and scenes from The Silver Eye will be included in this packet. One of them is a reversible Novalog, with day on one side and night on the other.

Original Art of a Character from The Silver Eye Webcomic

Along with your calendar and postcards, you can also have your own (6"x6") original marker drawing of The Silver Eye character of your choice! It will look something like this:

Not sure which character to choose? Take a look at the options below to jog your memory!

Original Artwork of Yosemite Valley

Interested in owning an entirely new original Yosemite study? Let me draw one for you! These pieces are on 6"x6" sketchbook paper and are done in marker.

Original Acrylic Painting

This original artwork features a view of the trail from Taft Point to Glacier Point, painted in acrylic on an 18"x24" canvas. This artwork is used for the month of July in the calendar.

 

Shipping: 

All packages will be shipped First Class Domestic and International. Tracking is not guaranteed. All items will be will be wrapped in protective sleeves. 

 

Timeline: 

November: Indiegogo!

Early December: Production begins, original art collected for perks, refunds (if any)

Mid-December: All orders shipped!

These dates may be sooner or later than listed. It all depends on how quickly the manufacturer is able to print and send the calendars. Please be patient. I will keep you updated on all progress!

 

Timeline:

This is my first crowdfunding campaign (wee!), but it isn’t my first rodeo in merchandising. I run The Silver Eye Etsy shop, where I’ve filled over 500 orders and have a 5-star rating. I've done calendars like this every year for four years. Additionally, in the last decade I’ve contracted and completed hundreds of commissions with individual clients. My goal is always to provide an excellent, beautiful product in a timely manner. 

I’ve done my very best to make sure all of this runs smoothly. In previous years, I’ve used this same manufacturer for smaller orders, so I know their quality will be good. 

Shipping will begin as soon as the campaign ends. The goal is to get these to you by Christmas, but I can’t make any guarantees. I haven’t yet fully mastered control of the postal service or the weather, so there may be unexpected delays. 

Please note that I’ll be shipping from the US. If you live overseas, the journey from my house to yours will be longer and slower. Please take that into account when you make your purchase.

 

Get the Word Out:

Like what you see? Please share the link, let your friends know, and/or use the Indiegogo share tools to put this out on your social media outlets. I appreciate it!

story:
MMAQ

Organisme à but non lucratif, la Maison des métiers d’art de Québec (MMAQ) est l’une des douze écoles ateliers en métiers d’art accréditées du Québec. Elle est la seule à regrouper trois disciplines en métiers d’art, soit la céramique, la sculpture et le textile.

Projet d’exposition des finissants 2020

Du 28 mai au 14 juin prochain, nos 13 finissants (textile, céramique et sculpture) présenteront une exposition de fin d’études au centre MATERIA, seul centre de diffusion professionnelle en métiers d’art dans l’Est du pays. Le montage de cette exposition et sa diffusion nécessiteront de nombreuses heures de travail minutieux ainsi que du matériel multiple (imprimés, vinyles, matériaux, socles…). Votre soutien nous permet de défrayer les coûts directs reliés à sa réalisation, et vous permet de vous procurer des items métiers d’art ! 100% des profits amassés iront à nos finissants.

Cohorte 2020

_____________________

Véronic Barbeau | Dominique Michaud | Léa Ménard | Gabrielle Dubois | Laurence Gagnon | Lorène Guignet | Maggie Jalbert | Catherine Lebel Ouellet | Chantal Turcotte | Isabelle Bouchard Lamontagne | Raoul Gasser Fillion | France Lareau |

Alissa Bilodeau

______________

 

Pourquoi soutenir notre projet ?

L’importance des métiers d’art et des savoir-faire

Trait d’union privilégié entre l’esprit et la main, l’esthétique et la fonction, les métiers d’art fondent un des socles essentiels de notre patrimoine culturel. L’importance de ces savoirs, de ces techniques et de ces œuvres est immense; ils ne doivent pas être oubliés mais plutôt préservés.

Une culture présente, dynamique et accessible

Notre événement culturel regroupe des créateurs motivés et ambitieux qui s’expriment à travers des objets et des œuvres de haut niveau, le tout de manière entièrement gratuite et ouverte à toute la communauté. Votre appui à la culture et à la relève en métiers d’art est essentiel afin de garantir la continuité de la diffusion de contenus actuels et innovants pour le grand public.

Un métier passionnant, stimulant et créatif !

En plus de démontrer l’importance que vous accordez à l’éducation en soutenant un événement couronnant une formation scolaire, vous démontrez aussi votre engagement à promouvoir l’art et la culture et à valoriser les métiers créatifs et artistiques. Une carrière en métiers d’art c’est accepter de relever un grand défi et d’avoir un mode de vie hors des sentiers battus!

Valoriser l’entreprenariat, l’achat local et un esprit éthique

Nos artistes créateurs sont des entrepreneurs d’ici, sensibles à la nature qui nous entoure et actifs dans la recherche de solutions durables. Ils fabriquent des objets à la main dans un contexte respectueux des ressources, des matériaux et de la main d’œuvre. Un objet ou une création de qualité que l’on aime, qui a un sens et qui porte l’histoire et la marque de son créateur peut nous suivre au quotidien pendant longtemps !

story:
Eric Hughes Band: "La Bluesicana"

Contributors to our project not only receive some of the best music and merchandise around, but also will help us create an album we ALL will be proud of... both the band and our listeners. 


  • We in the Eric Hughes Band bring to life the vibe, the wit and groove that have made our beloved city famous, and we carry the Memphis Music flag forward into onto new ground with "La Bluesicana".  
  • This will be our most interesting and eclectic album yet; lots of different styles.  The help of our fans through pre-ordering and contributing is VITAL in the creation of this new music.
  • Contributions will mean the difference between a home-made, low-budget, ordinary-sounding album that is poorly promoted- OR a gleaming piece of ear-candy that we can be proud of, and that can be enjoyed by more and more people.

We can't do it without you.

What We Need & What You Get

A few of the details about the "La Bluesicana"  fundraising campaign:

  • Funds from this campaign will go toward the booking of recording time in the studio and will pay for an engineer to record us.  These funds will also accomplish the mixing and mastering of this album.  The album's packaging, cover art, photography and manufacture are more goals for this fundraising campaign.  We are proud to add, by the way, that ALL of the processes mentioned above will be done in Memphis, using local businesses.  
  • Achieving the level of success that our previous albums have enjoyed is one way we plan to meet and even surpass the quality that our fans expect and deserve.  
  • The previous albums offered, our T-shirts, the stickers, plus the shot glasses, Eric's artwork and other perks offered to our contributors make GREAT gifts...for a friend, family member, or for yourself!

Help Us Make an Impact

Your participation is the difference between success and failure.

  • More than a mere collection of songs, "La Bluesicana" will be an invitation to the world that says: "Hey! ...listen to what Memphis sounds like these days!"  This new album will continue a Memphis tradition of hip, catchy, songwriting .
  • The track record of successful albums by the Eric Hughes Band speaks for itself.  "Muddy Mojo Award", "Memphis Songwriters Award", "Best Self Produced CD", "Coolest Blues Song"...with your help we can continue that tradition and deliver more of our original Memphis music.
  • Just as there is no show without an audience, there is no album without you: our friends, fans, family .

It Ain't Called "The Blues" For Nothing...

  • Being a musician in Memphis isn't without its challenges.  Despite low wages, fierce competition, and a sketchy economy, we continue to make music our business. After fifteen years we still choose to regularly perform at countless benefits, fundraisers, and charity concerts. What a beautiful thing it would be to get to see some of that karma returned through this campaign.  
  • As in the past, a lot of the band's own money will go toward this album's creation.  "La Bluesicana", however, will be partially funded by a loan made possible by Memphis Slim House, Community Lift, and River City Capital Investments.  Hughes is the first Memphis musician to be selected for this program, which is not only a vote of confidence but also a great honor.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please help make some noise about this album's campaign by spreading the word among your friends, family, and social media.
  • The "SHARE" tools provided throughout this campaign are easy, handy, and surprisingly effective.  You would be surprised how much it helps us reach our goal.

Most of all, THANKS for helping make our new album possible!!!

story:
The Magic Hour is...

A solo performance that uses magic to explore trauma and transformation. POOF!  Asks you to consider who you are beyond the stories you tell about your life. SHAZAM!  Stretches the boundaries between public and private, hidden and revealed, to make visible what is not seen. NOTHING UP MY SLEEVE!  Conjures a space where you can understand and imagine yourself as an active participant in creating social transformation. WATCH CAREFULLY! Asks you to envision a better future, to see into that world and place yourself there, to imagine what it would feel like. KEEP YOUR EYES ON THE PENDULUM!

My Name Is...

Jess Dobkin and I’m an artist based in Toronto, Canada. My performances and projects are presented in museums, galleries, festivals, theatres, universities and public spaces internationally. With support from The Theatre Centre Residency Program, and co-produced by The Theatre Centre, I’ve been developing The Magic Hour for three years. It is almost ready to make its way into the world, and I’m asking for your help to make it possible. I’m collaborating with a brilliant team of artists and designers including Stephen Lawson, Richard Feren, Jennifer Tipton, Michelle Ramsay, Bojana Stancic, Atom Cianfarani, and Sandra Henderson. Your contribution will help us cover costs of the production, including technicians, equipment and lighting rental and ASL interpretation, and help ensure it has a future life. The performance is designed to travel readily, with future performances on the horizon.

The Magic Hour premieres January 10-21 at The Theatre Centre and tickets go on sale November 15.

Other Ways You Can Help...

Please spread the word about this campaign. Sharing this link goes a long way. Visit The Magic Hour on Facebook and come see what's up our sleeves at The Theatre Centre in January.

#MagicHourTC

jessdobkin.com

theatrecentre.org

(photos by David Hawe)

story:
For the last 3 years Haus of Wire has brought a tight-wire out to Burningman.We received such a massive response from our single cable system, people came back day after day to get their tight-wire fix.  Some people would stay for hours balancing, and others would simply stop to take a snapshot of their first try. This year, we want to take it further.  In addition to the 2ft. cable, we want to add a 4&6ft cable, a safety perimeter and a lighting system(for evening use) & a shaded stretching area to allow longer daytime use. Help us to bring the Temple of Tension to Burningman 2017.

Estelle Borel, a Swiss Wire-Walker & Temple of Tension Collaborator  standing on our 2ft platforms from Burningman 2014. This was our first attempt at a zero budget tight-wire install on playa.

Tight-wire walking is an ancient craft, passed down through the centuries by masters. The Temple of Tension seeks to awaken a new passion and understanding for this beautiful but scarce art form. 

photo by : Rae Candent, a second install of the prototype platforms for 4th of Juplaya in 2016, teaching a twilight class to friends.

The balance playground will be a contemporary twist on the basic two-platform design of old. We mix it up by creating 4 additional platforms and a total of three interlaced cables that allow participants to walk, climb and jump from one level to the next while remaining on the wire. If we  are able to reach our maximum funding goal, we will not only be able to bring out our 3-level cable system, but it will also allow us to install a shade structure for stretching & beautiful lighting system for evening use! (concept art below)

 

We have lots of fantastic perks that come along with contributing to the campaign, everything from t-shirts and patches with the temple logo:

to one on one tight-wire lessons with our professional team!

With your help, we will have the infrastructure to bring the Temple of Tension all over the world.  Every little bit helps, even if you can only donate a dollar, you would be contributing to large-scale interactive art that will last for decades. If you aren't able to contribute $$$, consider sharing our campaign on Facebook and other social media platforms for greater visibility.

story:
Federation of Youth Clubs of Armenia (FYCA) was founded in 1999 by uniting several youth clubs, which had a 17 year history. It now unites more than 90 youth clubs, centres and organisations from all over Armenia. FYCA’s aims are: advocating the benefits of open youth work, to organize seminars, joint training of workers and programs of youth exchange,  encourage active involvement of young people in their community, promote youth work in the region, to develop youth information, counseling and research centres, promote intercultural learning and sustainable development. 
Vardavar is a festival in Armenia where people  pour each other with water. The ancient festival is traditionally associated with the goddess Astghik, who was the goddess of water, beauty, love and fertility. The festivities associated with this religious observance of Astghik were named “Vartavar” because Armenians offered her roses as a celebration , this is why it was celebrated in the harvest time. During the day of Vardavar, people from a wide array of ages are allowed to pour strangers with water. It is common to see people pouring buckets of water from balconies on unsuspecting people walking below them. The festival is very popular among children as it is one day where they can get away with pulling pranks. It is also a means of refreshment on the usually hot and dry summer days of July.
It is already 2 years Federation of Youth Clubs of Armenia is organizing Vardavar International Festival and more then 150 young people participate from EU and USA.
The festival will be organized at the marvelous temple of Garni  and Geghard Monastery, masterpiece of the 13th century architecture.
Festival is dedicated to the Vardavar Holiday aiming to preserve national traditions. Great musical theatre is set to be performed by Armenian folk ensembles and actors, folk dances and songs are part of the festival. Opening ceremony of the pavilions dedicated to Vardavar Holiday will be organized on spot, which will include presentation of national traditions of celebrating Vardavar, exhibition of thematic handmade accessories, Armenian cuisine, etc.
The amount that is set for Festival is for transport, dresses and techniques that should be used by the organizers.

story:
Welcome to a Campaign set up to introduce the work of Australian Artist, Tim Prosser.

A long and diverse career as a scenic artist, props and modelmaker in television and theatre has given Tim a background which has resulted in these wonderful images.

Tim has many ‘fans’ already of his work; those who he has worked with during the years, in the artistic and theatre communities, plus more recently,  members of modelling and aviation-related internet forums abounding around the world. Really just anyone else who happens to see something he has created.

After many years of producing some unique work, particularly like those offered here, we are, finally,  aiming to produce a full colour calendar of his breathtaking ‘Model Aircraft in Flight’ – the first of an eventual series. (And there are definitely enough photos for it!)

A collection of stunning full colour photographs of Model Aircraft in Flight, by talented artist Tim Prosser, offered as a 12 month bound calendar.

This campaign will also see the set-up achieved for several other items offered, both here and later on. The Calendar, obviously, but also a collection of posters, postcard sets, some limited editions, plus various commission works for Tim to create in the future.

Tim has a large amount of work not yet seen and with that we wish to endeavour to create a series of collections that will showcase his amazing art.

This collection of images of model aircraft in flight, finely detailed, many originally photographed on 35mm film, are just as incredible as their creation.

These are extensively re-worked models, incorporating scatch-built details and realistic paint finishing, then photographed on glass over original hand painted backdrops. They are all ‘one of a kind’ – and bring wonderful realism to the images created.

 “ You do think these are ‘real’... real aircraft, in the air! Amazing! ”

There's no Photoshop here...just good old-fashioned inventive talent.

 

What We Need & What You Get

For this project to succeed, we need help to pay for the printing of the calendars, 'up front', as it were, which is why we need YOUR help with pre-orders!

Please take advantage of the ‘perks’ we’ve offered and know we are grateful for all your assistance in making a dream come true, by contributing in any way you can to this campaign.

And please ‘spread the word’ to others who might be interested.

All investments, from small to large, will be very gratefully received with our thanks, for helping make a wonderful idea actually happen.

There are quite a few different contributions for this calendar and the print run of ephemera.

From only $15 upwards … for a full color, high resolution digital-only version of the calendar to $50 dollars where you receive one signed copy of the calendar shipped to your address AND a copy of the digital version to tide you over while your real copy arrives!

Also many other very special and unique commissions. Please see below for further details on these and feel free to contact one of the team to discuss any questions you may have on timprosserart@gmail.com

Particularly collectible for the Aircraft Enthusiast!

Also included are limited edition prints and posters. Hopefully something that will appeal to most.

The funds raised with this campaign will allow us to print the calendars, (quality printers aren’t cheap) the posters, postcards, and art materials for future art projects.

In addition to some very special ‘perks’ there is also a very special ‘Milestone’ Prize!

When we reach our $5,000 initial goal, we will award a prize, drawn randomly from all the contributors,  to win their choice of five Limited Edition Prints images from the current range available – these will be signed and numbered by Tim. Plus a set of the 12 sepia Limited Edition postcards.

We also ask …

That you take into account, the calendar and all other images, photos and artwork took Tim hours upon hours and weeks and weeks of work in total to do. He pours every ounce of his talent into the images he creates.

 

So, that being said, once you get the digital copies of the pictures - PLEASE do NOT redistribute the pictures anywhere online, or upload them anywhere! You can, of course, show them to your friends, but if they like them as well, ask them to consider donating so that they can get copies of their own. And if one person gets the calendar only to spread the pictures or scan them then spread them around, we would have spent the money to make this happen for nothing! WE WILL EVENTUALLY upload the pictures to the internet in a MUCH smaller file format without the calendar information, and probably crop them, but you will be receiving, first hand, the artwork in full resolution.


So we thank you all in advance for reading this and following the rules.

 

If this all goes smoothly, we will be excited to continue with the SECOND version of the calendar very soon! Which will be a 16 month version of NEW images !!!

Also just so everyone knows... The digital calendars will ONLY BE sent out once the campaign is over.

Special Commissions

These commissions are only available in very limited numbers – Tim can only paint ‘so fast’!

So they are a very unique opportunity to own something very special.

$5000 – one of Tim’s amazing oil paintings – an aircraft of your choice! 1000 x 600mm Full color!

$8000 - Commission extravaganza! Two commissions available. Not one, but TWO very special commissions – two of Tim’s very unique oil paintings – aircraft of your choice! Both 1000 x 600mm. Full color!

 

$10,000 This is a very special Commission extravaganza PLUS much more!

Two commissions available. Not one, but TWO very special commissions – two of Tim’s unique oil paintings – aircraft of your choice! Both 1000 x 600mm. Full color!

PLUS: a digital copy of the calendar (with full resolution artwork) AND one of the printed calendars, also signed by the artist and mailed to your address.

PLUS: FIVE full color LIMITED EDITION prints of your choice from the gallery, signed and numbered by the artist, Tim Prosser.

PLUS: a full color set of 12 postcards of THE IMAGES ON THE CALENDAR.

PLUS: a special limited edition sepia set also of the 12 postcards.

 

ALSO AS AN ADDED EXTRA - if we manage to raise $10,000 ...

WE WILL DONATE $1000 TO … The Red Cross Australia

story:
Our Story

My name is Ben Clarkson and I am an artist and an illustrator from Winnipeg, Manitoba, Canada, North America, The world, etc.... I am starting an art subscription service where in exchange for 45 bones (USD) you get a limited edition print of one of my drawings, paintings, or collages, once a month, for a year. That's 12 pieces of art for less than 5 bucks each, and you get a signed print, and something in the mail that's not a bill. 

The prints will be from limited one time editions of around 50. Eventually they'll also be archival as I figure out what I am doing. 


The Impact

If I don't get a bunch of people on board for this I will starve. Art is difficult and time consuming, and I need the subscriptions to be able to afford my very humble lifestyle. 


What We Need & What You Get

I need a bunch of people to sign up, and to enjoy the art you get.


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends about it.

story:
The 2013 YouTube FTM* Calendar!

*FTM stands for Female To Male. 

A calendar created by the youtube trans* masculine community to fundraise for transition related expenses such as legal name and gender marker changes, therapist fees and female to male surgeries. 

The mastermind and photographer behind this project is Alex (aka alexhaney100 on youtube). Also featuring as models: Elliott (smittyschair), Kaden (DrunkenLullaby52), Yovi (the1yovi), Eli (Chisis), Kipling (kypharrop), Benjamin (herrbenjaminkalt), Izaac (IzaacsMind), Val (valjamesP), Chase (uppercaseCHASE1), Ming (tubefedjade), Ro (RoStud11), Kinnon (SkinninMacKinnon) and Kadyn (leesh924). 

What We Need & What You Get

We need to reach our fundraising goal of $5000 by October, 15 2012 in order to get this calendar printed!! If we do not reach this goal, all of your donations will be refunded and the calendar will not be printed. 

The calendars will ONLY be sold through pre-sales on this website, so get yours now!

Your contributions will cover production costs, custom design of the calendar, printing, shipping and handling. All proceeds go towards transition related fundraising. Fifty percent of proceeds will go towards Alex's top surgery fund, with the remaining fifty percent divided amongst those involved in the calendar with their own transition related expenses. 

For a more detailed breakdown of exactly where every dollar will go, please see this video: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=WfwDSlCQyaM

You can donate any amount from as little as $5. There are different rewards for each contribution amount. The bigger the contribution, the bigger the reward!!! Each backer will receive e-mail updates about project progress, including photos and video.

The fridge magnet calendar, gold star funder and featured funder all include shipping and handling to any address domestic or international. If you are purchasing just the calendar, there is an extra $10 shipping and handling fee for international orders. 

Who is the Photographer? 

Alex Haney is a transmasculine person living in Toronto, Ontario. He holds a college certificate in fine art photography and is currently working towards a bachelor of fine arts in Photography. You can view his bio and some of his other work on his website: imagearts.ryerson.ca/chaney or see him on youtube under the username alexhaney100.

The photographs were all captured using a medium format film camera, developed by hand by Alex in his home darkroom. The resulting images are gorgeous, high resolution black and white which surpass the image quality produced by most professional digital cameras available today. Each image is professionally scanned, and the calendar will be custom designed and printed at a local printing press. 

The Impact of Your Donation

Your contribution will be greatly appreciated by an amazing group of trans-masculine folks from across the United States and Canada. Gender transition can be incredibly expensive, and every dollar helps us feel more whole, happy and at peace in our bodies and in our lives! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially, you can still help. 

Spread the word! 

Tell your friends, family, coworkers and classmates! 

Link the project on facebook, twitter, youtube, tumblr!
